steps.title: Cut your nails straight across.
steps.content: Cut your nails straight across. When you cut your nails at an angle, you create more chances for a sharp edge to dig into your flesh. Use nail clippers that cut in an even, straight line. Hold your clippers upright and keep them parallel to your toe as you cut. Pay special attention to the corners of your toes so that you don’t cut them at an angle. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Avoid cutting your nails too short.
steps.content: Avoid cutting your nails too short. The most common cause of ingrown nails is cutting your nails too short. Try not to cut below the white tip of your nails. If you expose the soft, pink skin underneath your nails, you’ve cut too far. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you get manicures or pedicures, make sure the technician knows not to cut your nails too short.

steps.title: Cut your nails more often if they curve naturally.
steps.content: Cut your nails more often if they curve naturally. If you get a lot of ingrown toenails, it may be because your nails naturally grow in a curved fashion. Keep an eye on your nails and make sure that they are growing in a straight line after you cut them. Cut them back more often if you need to correct a curve. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If anyone in your family has a history of ingrown toenails, curved toenails may run in your family.

steps.title: Wear shoes that don’t crowd your toes.
steps.content: Wear shoes that don’t crowd your toes. If your toes are constantly shoved into ill-fitting shoes, it may cause your nails to grow at an angle which can cause ingrown nails. Make sure the shoes you wear on a daily basis fit your feet well and don’t squish or crowd your feet. Measure your feet before you buy a new pair of shoes, especially if you are on your feet all day at your job. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Wear the correct shoes when you play sports.
steps.content: Wear the correct shoes when you play sports. Sports where you kick a ball, like soccer, and dance genres where you are up on your toes, like ballet, can increase your chances of getting an ingrown toenail. Wear proper shoes and socks for your sport that fit you well, trim your toenails regularly, and let your feet rest without shoes on for a few hours after doing a sport that requires you to use your toes. [5] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Protect your feet with the correct footwear during a manual labor job.
steps.content: Protect your feet with the correct footwear during a manual labor job. If you are on your feet for work every day, you put your toes at risk of trauma. Heavy equipment falling on your toes can damage the nails and cause them to grow at an angle, increasing your chances of an ingrown toenail. Wear work boots that have a hard, protective cover for your toes during the day. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source If you work in construction or near large animals, you may want to wear steel-toed boots.

steps.title: Avoid walking around barefoot to prevent stubbed toes.
steps.content: Avoid walking around barefoot to prevent stubbed toes. Stubbing your toes can cause ingrown toenails since it makes your feet swell. Try to wear shoes as much as you can, even around the house, to avoid stubbing your toes on stray chairs or table legs. [7] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source If you don’t want to wear your dirty shoes inside, purchase a pair of house slippers.

steps.title: Check your feet daily for the start of an ingrown toenail.
steps.content: Check your feet daily for the start of an ingrown toenail. People with poor circulation due to diabetes may not be able to feel the start of an ingrown toenail since their foot sensitivity is low. If you have circulation or sensitivity issues in your feet, check them once a day to look for ingrown toenails. Catching them early can prevent further pain and irritation. [8] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source You can spot ingrown toenails by looking for redness or irritation at the corners of your nails.

steps.title: Soak your toes in warm water and Epsom salt.
steps.content: Soak your toes in warm water and Epsom salt. Epsom salts can help reduce swelling and tenderness around your ingrown toenail. Fill a bucket with warm water and 2 tbsp (10 g) of Epsom salt. Soak your feet in the water and salt for about 10 minutes, or until your feet feel warm and the skin feels soft. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can buy Epsom salt at most home goods or beauty supply stores. Epsom salt is also great for soothing baths.

steps.title: Clip back the ingrown toenail.
steps.content: Clip back the ingrown toenail. Use nail clippers to gently pry the toenail away from your skin. Cut the corner that is digging into your skin back with your clippers. Try to cut it in a straight line so that it doesn’t become ingrown again as it grows out. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply an antibiotic cream to prevent infection.
steps.content: Apply an antibiotic cream to prevent infection. Put a pea-sized dab of antibiotic cream over the area that you cut back. Cover the cream with a bandage and leave it on for about 1 day. Ingrown toenails can get infected easily, so it is important to remove any threat of germs. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have poor circulation in your feet, it is extremely important to prevent infection with an antibiotic cream. For a natural alternative to antibiotic creams, try tea tree oil, eucalyptus oil, or coconut oil. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source [14] X Research source

steps.title: See a podiatrist for severe or recurring ingrown toenails.
steps.content: See a podiatrist for severe or recurring ingrown toenails. If your ingrown toenail looks really red or is leaking pus, it might be infected. If you have had more than 2 ingrown toenails in 1 month, you may have chronic ingrown toenails. Visit a podiatrist to see how you can best prevent and treat your ingrown toenails. [15] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source In some extreme cases, you may need surgery to fix your ingrown toenails.
